document.docAuthor: Shah, Syed Ishfaq Ali, Ahmad, Azaz, Li, Hu & Cai, Wanzhi
document.masterDocTitle: First record of Holoptilinae from Pakistan, with the redescription of Holoptilus fasciatus (Hemiptera: Reduviidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: First record of Holoptilinae from Pakistan, with the redescription of Holoptilus fasciatus (Hemiptera: Reduviidae)

bibRefCitation.author: Reuter, O. M.
bibRefCitation.refString: Reuter, O. M. (1881) Ad cognitionem Reduviidarum mundi antiqui. Acta Societatis Scientiarum Fennicae, 12, 269 - 339.

subSubSection.paragraph: Redescription. Macropterous male. Colouration: Dorsum of head, antennae, margins of pronotum, posterior portion of scutellum, veins of corium, legs, connexivum golden yellow or flavous; venter of head, labium, ventrolateral thoracic area, acetabula including coxae dark-mustard; eyes and ocelli flavous-ferruginous; fore lobe of pronotum brown while hind lobe dark-mustard with combination of white adpressed hairs; base of scutellum piceous; hemelytra diaphanous, white, cream and piceous colored; cells of corium and clavus hyaline; hind wings diaphanous milky white; abdomen flavous-ferruginous, anteriorly abdomen golden yellow while the rest portion with dark-mustard, dark-brownish and piceous.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1.
Holoptilus fasciatus Reuter, 1881
, ♂, habitus. Scale bar = 1.00 mm.

FIGURES 2–5.
Holoptilus
fasciatus
Reuter, 1881
. 2, Head, notum and scutellum; 3, head and stridulitrum; 4, head and notum; 5, antenna. 2, 5, dorsal view; 3, ventral view; 4, lateral view. Scale bar of 2, 4 = 0.5 mm; of 3 = 0.25 mm; of 5 = 1.0 mm.

FIGURES 6–7.
Holoptilus fasciatus
Reuter, 1881
. 6, Hemelytron; 7, hindwing. 6, 7, dorsal view. Scale bar of 6 = 1.0 mm; of 7 = 0.5 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Measurements [in mm, ♂ (n=4)]. Body length to apex of forewing = 5.71–6.44; body length to apex of abdo- men = 3.61; length of head = 0.91–0.94; width across eyes = 0.88; interocular distance = 0.55; interocellar distance = 0.26–0.29; anteocular distance = 0.39–0.40; postocular distance = 0.38–0.50; lengths of antennal segments I, II, III, IV = 0.35, 3.10–3.25, 0.41, 0.55–0.59; lengths of visible labial segments I, II, III = 0.82–0.84, 0.15–0.16, 0.14; length of pronotum along meson = 0.91–0.94, humeral width = 1.98–2.00; length of scutellum = 0.52–0.65; basal width of scutellum = 0.21–0.26; length of forewing = 5.45–5.85; greatest width of forewing = 2.15–2.25; length of hindwing = 2.35–2.45; lengths of fore femur, tibia, tarsus and pretarsus = 1.25–1.41, 1.60–2.00, 0.45–0.53, 0.13– 0.15; length of mid femur, tibia, tarsus and pretarsus = 1.30–1.35, 2.00–2.08, 0.48–0.51, 0.15–0.17; length of hind femur, tibia, tarsus and pretarsus = 1.61–1.72, 3.85–3.91, 0.50–0.57, 0.15–0.17; length of abdomen = 1.91–2.21; greatest width of abdomen = 1.79–1.81.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 8–12.
Holoptilus
fasciatus
Reuter, 1881
. 8, 11–12, Abdomen; 9–10, paramere. 8, 9–10 dorsal view; 11, lateral view; 12, ventral view. Scale bar of 8–12 = 0.5mm.

FIGURES 13–18.
Holoptilus
fasciatus Reuter, 1881
. 13 – 15, Pygophore; 16 – 18, phallus. 13, 16, dorsal view; 14, 17, lateral view; 15, 18, ventral view. Scale bar of 13 – 15 = 0.5 mm; of 16–18 = 1.0 mm.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Pakistan , Khyber Pakhtunkhwa , Khyber Agency , Tirah Valley ,
viii.2017
, leg. Syed Ishfaq Ali Shah.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Pakistan ( Khyber Pakhtunkhwa , new record); India ( West Bengal ).

Remarks.
Holoptilus fasciatus
is similar to
H. melanospilus ( Walker, 1873 )
morphologically, but it can easily be separated from the latter by the smaller body size (about 6 mm in
H. fasciatus
vs. about 8 mm in
H. melanospilus
), fore wing twice as long as abdomen (vs. fore wing more than twice as long as abdomen in
H. melanospilus
), and the different fore wing pattern (bigger and darker apical patch in
H. fasciatus
vs. smaller and incomplete patch in
H. melanospilus
).

Biological notes. Specimens of
H. fasciatus
were collected from low spineless bushes far from cultivated areas, near spiny shrubs ( Fig. 19 ) during the partial cloudy weather in late afternoon, using a sweep net. Tirah Valley is a relatively cold locality within Pakistan .
